docs.title: Add a New Chaos Experiment Type
docs.description: This document describes how to add a new chaos experiment type.

docs.title: Basic Features
docs.description: This document describes the basic features of Chaos Mesh, including fault injection, Chaos workflows, visualized operations, and security guarantees.

docs.title: Chaosctl
docs.description: Chaosctl is a tool to assist in debugging Chaos Mesh. With Chaosctl, you can simplify the process of developing and debugging new chaos types, and provide references for other developers when raising an issue.

docs.title: Chaosd Introduction
docs.description: Chaosd introduction

docs.title: Search and Recover Experiments of Chaosd
docs.description: You can search experiments by conditions and recover the experiments corresponding to specified UIDs using Chaosd. This document describes how to search and recover experiments of Chaosd, and provides releated examples.

frontMatter.title: Search and Recover Experiments of Chaosd
frontMatter.summary: Describes how to search and recover the experiments of Chaosd, and provide related examples.

docs.description: This document describes how to configure a local development environment for Chaos Mesh.

docs.description: This chapter walks you through how to configure Chaos experiments to only take effect in the specified namespace, and protect other unspecified namespaces against fault injection.

docs.description: At times, you may need to make the Chaos Dashboard accessible to external users, while placing it under the subpath of your current monitoring dashboard.

docs.description: In Add a new chaos experiment type, you have added HelloWorldChaos, which can print Hello world! in the logs of Chaos Controller Manager.

docs.title: Run a Chaos Experiment
docs.description: This document describes how to create, run, view, pause, update, and delete Chaos experiments in Chaos Mesh.

docs.title: Serial and Parallel Experiments
docs.description: Chaos Mesh Workflow offers two ways of scheduling experiments: serial and parallel. You can configure and schedule multiple experiments as needed.

docs.title: Rust
docs.description: TODO

docs.title: Send HTTP Requests on Workflow
docs.description: Chaos Mesh Workflow provides a Task node to support any workload, similar to Kubernetes Job. To make the user experience more convenient, Chaos Dashboard provides a template based on Task to create HTTP requests in WebUI.

docs.title: Simulate AWS Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaos Mesh to simulate AWS faults.

docs.title: Simulate Azure Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaos Mesh to simulate Azure faults.

docs.title: Simulate Block Device Incidents
docs.description: BlockChaos Introduction

docs.title: Simulate Disk Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaosd to simulate disk faults. This feature helps you simulate disk read/write load (via dd) or disk fill (via dd or fallocate).

docs.title: Simulate DNS Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to create DNSChaos experiments in Chaos Mesh to simulate DNS faults.

docs.title: Simulate File Faults
docs.description: TODO

docs.title: Simulate GCP Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaos Mesh to inject faults into GCP Pod. Chaos Dashboard and YAML files are provided to create GCPChaos experiments.

docs.title: Simulate Stress Scenarios
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaosd to simulate stress scenarios. This feature generates CPU or memory stress on the host using stress-ng. You can create stress experiments either in command-line or service mode.

docs.title: Simulate Stress Scenarios
docs.description: StressChaos Introduction

docs.title: Simulate Host Faults
docs.description: This document introduces how to simulate host shutdown faults using Chaosd.

docs.title: Simulate HTTP Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to simulate HTTP faults by creating HTTPChaos experiments in Chaos Mesh.

docs.title: Simulate File I/O Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to create IOChaos experiments in Chaos Mesh.

docs.title: Simulate JVM Application Faults
docs.description: Chaos Mesh simulates the faults of JVM application through Byteman. The supported fault types are as follows:

docs.title: Simulate JVM Application Faults
docs.description: Chaosd simulates the faults of JVM application through Byteman. The supported fault types are as follows:

docs.title: Simulate Linux Kernel Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use KernelChaos to simulate Linux kernel faults. This feature injects I/O-based or memory-based faults into the specified kernel paths using BPF.

docs.title: Simulate Network Faults
docs.description: This document introduces how to use Chaosd to simulate network faults. The simulations can be completed by modifying network routing and traffic flow control using iptables, ipsets, tc, etc.

docs.title: Simulate Network Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to simulate network faults using NetworkChaos in Chaos Mesh.

docs.title: Simulate Faults on Physical Machines
docs.description: This document describes how to create PhysicalMachineChaos (physical machine chaos) experiments in Chaos Mesh to simulate the faults of network, disk, pressure, JVM, time, and others in physical or virtual machines.

docs.title: Simulate Pod Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaos Mesh to inject faults into Kubernetes Pod to simulate Pod or container faults. Chaos Dashboard and YAML files are provided to create PodChaos experiments.

docs.title: Simulate Process Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaosd to simulate process faults. The process faults use the Golang interface of the kill command to simulate the scenarios that the process is killed or stopped. You can create experiments either in the command-line mode or service mode.

docs.title: Simulate Redis Faults
docs.description: This document introduces how to use Chaosd to simulate Redis faults. This feature uses Golang interfaces in go-redis package and the redis-server command-line tool. You can create experiments either in command-line mode or service mode.

next.title: Search and Recover Experiments of Chaosd

docs.title: Simulate Time Faults
docs.description: TimeChaos Introduction

docs.title: Simulate Time Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaosd to simulate a time offset scenario. You can create experiments either in command-line mode or service mode.

frontMatter.title: Simulate Time Faults
frontMatter.summary: This document describes how to use Chaosd to simulate a time offset scenario.

docs.title: Status Check in Workflow
docs.description: In Workflow, the status check could execute specified operations on external systems, such as application systems and monitoring systems, to obtain their statuses, and automatically abort the Workflow when it finds the system is unhealthy. The concept is similar to Container Probes in Kubernetes. This article describes how to execute status checks in Workflow using YAML files.

docs.title: 故障排查
docs.description: TODO

docs.title: Uninstall Chaos Mesh
docs.description: This document introduces how to uninstall Chaos Mesh, including uninstall Chaos Mesh with Helm and uninstall Chaos Mesh manually. It's also very helpful to manually purge Chaos Mesh installation from Kubernetes cluster if you have to do.

docs.title: Upgrade from 2.1 to 2.2
docs.description: There are several changes in Helm Charts 2.2.0 release. This documentation introduces how to migrate from 2.1.x to 2.2.0.

docs.title: Upgrade to Chaos Mesh 2.0
docs.description: This document provides detailed instruction for upgrading Chaos Mesh from 1.x to 2.0. Chaos Mesh 2.0 introduced some new features and fixed many issues. Because in Chaos Mesh 2.0, some code has been rebuilt, you need to perform extra actions for the upgrade.

docs.title: Simulate File Faults
docs.description: TODO

docs.title: Simulate GCP Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaos Mesh to inject faults into GCP Pod. Chaos Dashboard and YAML files are provided to create GCPChaos experiments.

docs.title: Simulate Stress Scenarios
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaosd to simulate stress scenarios. This feature generates CPU or memory stress on the host using stress-ng. You can create stress experiments either in command-line or service mode.

docs.title: Simulate Stress Scenarios
docs.description: StressChaos Introduction

docs.title: Simulate Host Faults
docs.description: This document introduces how to simulate host shutdown faults using Chaosd.

docs.title: Simulate HTTP Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to simulate HTTP faults by creating HTTPChaos experiments in Chaos Mesh.

docs.title: Simulate File I/O Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to create IOChaos experiments in Chaos Mesh.

docs.title: Simulate JVM Application Faults
docs.description: Chaos Mesh simulates the faults of JVM application through Byteman. The supported fault types are as follows:

docs.title: Simulate JVM Application Faults
docs.description: Chaosd simulates the faults of JVM application through Byteman. The supported fault types are as follows:

docs.title: Simulate Linux Kernel Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use KernelChaos to simulate Linux kernel faults. This feature injects I/O-based or memory-based faults into the specified kernel paths using BPF.

docs.title: Simulate Network Faults
docs.description: This document introduces how to use Chaosd to simulate network faults. The simulations can be completed by modifying network routing and traffic flow control using iptables, ipsets, tc, etc.

docs.title: Simulate Network Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to simulate network faults using NetworkChaos in Chaos Mesh.

docs.title: Simulate Faults on Physical Machines
docs.description: This document describes how to create PhysicalMachineChaos (physical machine chaos) experiments in Chaos Mesh to simulate the faults of network, disk, pressure, JVM, time, and others in physical or virtual machines.

docs.title: Simulate Pod Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaos Mesh to inject faults into Kubernetes Pod to simulate Pod or container faults. Chaos Dashboard and YAML files are provided to create PodChaos experiments.

docs.title: Simulate Process Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaosd to simulate process faults. The process faults use the Golang interface of the kill command to simulate the scenarios that the process is killed or stopped. You can create experiments either in the command-line mode or service mode.

docs.title: Simulate Redis Faults
docs.description: This document introduces how to use Chaosd to simulate Redis faults. This feature uses Golang interfaces in go-redis package and the redis-server command-line tool. You can create experiments either in command-line mode or service mode.

next.title: Search and Recover Experiments of Chaosd

docs.title: Simulate Time Faults
docs.description: TimeChaos Introduction

docs.title: Simulate Time Faults
docs.description: This document describes how to use Chaosd to simulate a time offset scenario. You can create experiments either in command-line mode or service mode.

frontMatter.title: Simulate Time Faults
frontMatter.summary: This document describes how to use Chaosd to simulate a time offset scenario.

docs.title: Status Check in Workflow
docs.description: In Workflow, the status check could execute specified operations on external systems, such as application systems and monitoring systems, to obtain their statuses, and automatically abort the Workflow when it finds the system is unhealthy. The concept is similar to Container Probes in Kubernetes. This article describes how to execute status checks in Workflow using YAML files.

docs.description: TODO

docs.title: Uninstall Chaos Mesh
docs.description: This document introduces how to uninstall Chaos Mesh, including uninstall Chaos Mesh with Helm and uninstall Chaos Mesh manually. It's also very helpful to manually purge Chaos Mesh installation from Kubernetes cluster if you have to do.

docs.title: Upgrade from 2.1 to 2.2
docs.description: There are several changes in Helm Charts 2.2.0 release. This documentation introduces how to migrate from 2.1.x to 2.2.0.

docs.title: Upgrade to Chaos Mesh 2.0
docs.description: This document provides detailed instruction for upgrading Chaos Mesh from 1.x to 2.0. Chaos Mesh 2.0 introduced some new features and fixed many issues. Because in Chaos Mesh 2.0, some code has been rebuilt, you need to perform extra actions for the upgrade.

docs.description: This document describes the basic features of Chaos Mesh, including fault injection, Chaos workflows, visualized operations, and security guarantees.

docs.title: Chaosctl
docs.description: Chaosctl is a tool to assist in debugging Chaos Mesh. With Chaosctl, you can simplify the process of developing and debugging new chaos types, and provide references for other developers when raising an issue.

docs.title: Search and Recover Experiments of Chaosd
docs.description: You can search experiments by conditions and recover the experiments corresponding to specified UIDs using Chaosd. This document describes how to search and recover experiments of Chaosd, and provides releated examples.

frontMatter.summary: Describes how to search and recover the experiments of Chaosd, and provide related examples.

docs.description: This chapter walks you through how to configure Chaos experiments to only take effect in the specified namespace, and protect other unspecified namespaces against fault injection.

docs.title: Developer Guide Overview
docs.description: This document describes how to develop Chaos Mesh. Before you start, it is recommended to first read the following documents:

docs.title: Extend Chaos Daemon Interface
docs.description: In Add new chaos experiment type, you have added HelloWorldChaos, which can print Hello World! in the logs of Chaos Controller Manager. To enable the HelloWorldChaos to inject some faults into the target Pod, you need to extend interface for Chaos Daemon.

docs.title: GCP OAuth Authentication
docs.description: When Chaos Mesh is deployed on the Google Cloud Platform, you can log in to Chaos Dashboard through Google OAuth. This document describes how to enable and configure this function.

docs.description: Chaos Mesh Workflow offers two ways of scheduling experiments: serial and parallel. You can configure and schedule multiple experiments as needed.

docs.title: Send HTTP Requests on Workflow
docs.description: Chaos Mesh Workflow provides a Task node to support any workload, similar to Kubernetes Job. To make the user experience more convenient, Chaos Dashboard provides a template based on Task to create HTTP requests in WebUI.
